moves.1... c5 2. Bg2 Nf6 3. Nf3 g6 4. O-O Bg7: Per the database Nc6 seems like a stronger move for black, though this move is the most common response.
moves.5. d4 cxd4 6. Qxd4 O-O 7. Bg5 Nc6 8. Qd2: Bg4 temporarily pins the black knight.
moves.30. Bg4 Rd8 31. Ne4 Nd4 32. e3 Nc2 33. a: Oops, white is vulnerable to a pawn fork of his knight and bishop.
...and there it is.  White is able to recover since the black rook is pinned.
moves.38. Bf3 fxe4 39. Bxe4 Bc3 40. Rxd5: Bxd5+ seems better.  41. Rd3 counter threats the black bishop, and white can defend the white bishop with e4, freeing up his rook with a pawn advance.
moves.40... Rxd5 41. Bxd5+: On the other hand, forcing a trade while up two pawns also plays to white's advantage.
moves.41... Kf8 42. Kg2 g5 43. f4 gxf4 44. gxf: The bishops are invisible to each other--it will be hard to force a trade.  But white should be able to force the black king to move by advancing pawns.
